animalOfTheDay.name: turkey
facts: Wild turkeys can fly short distances at speeds of up to 55 mph.
They have excellent vision and can see in color, with a nearly 360-degree field of view.
Male turkeys, called toms, puff up their feathers and fan their tails to attract females.
Benjamin Franklin once proposed the turkey as the national bird of the United States.

calendar.name: termite
facts: They cultivate fungi in their nests as a food source.
Some termite mounds can be over 30 feet tall and contain millions of individuals.
Termites are more closely related to cockroaches than to ants.
Termite queens can live up to 50 years, making them among the longest-living insects.

calendar.name: tiger shark
facts: They are born with distinctive stripes that fade as they mature.
Tiger sharks are one of the few shark species that can tolerate freshwater.
They have unique, saw-like teeth that can cut through turtle shells.
Tiger sharks are called 'garbage cans of the sea' because they'll eat almost anything.

calendar.name: toad
facts: Some toads, like the cane toad, have become invasive species in certain regions.
Toads are more terrestrial than frogs and are often found far from water.
Toads have dry, warty skin, while frogs have smooth, moist skin.
They secrete toxins from their skin to deter predators, which can be harmful if ingested.

calendar.name: topi
facts: Topis are fast antelopes that can reach speeds of up to 50 mph.
They have a unique 'pronking' behavior where they leap stiff-legged when alarmed.
They have specialized scent glands that help them mark their territory.
Male topis defend small territories where females come to mate.

calendar.name: trout
facts: Some trout species migrate between freshwater and saltwater during their life cycle.
They can detect vibrations in the water through their lateral line system.
They are indicators of clean water and are sensitive to pollution.
Trout have excellent vision and can see in color.

calendar.name: sloth
facts: Sloths are the slowest mammals on Earth, moving at a top speed of about 0.24 km/h.
They spend most of their lives hanging upside down in trees, even sleeping and giving birth in this position.
Sloths have a symbiotic relationship with algae, which grows on their fur and provides camouflage.
They only come down from the trees about once a week to defecate.

calendar.name: turkey
facts: They have excellent vision and can see in color, with a nearly 360-degree field of view.
Wild turkeys can fly short distances at speeds of up to 55 mph.
Male turkeys, called toms, puff up their feathers and fan their tails to attract females.
Benjamin Franklin once proposed the turkey as the national bird of the United States.

randomAnimals.name: tree kangaroo
facts: Their front paws are stronger and more dexterous than those of ground kangaroos, with sharp claws for climbing.
They feed on leaves, fruits, ferns, and tree bark.
They have long, prehensile tails that help them maintain balance and climb branches.
Tree kangaroos are species of kangaroos that, instead of hopping on the ground, live in trees, in the rainforests of New Guinea and Australia.

randomAnimals.name: lion
facts: Lions are the only big cats that live in social groups called prides.
A lion's roar can be heard up to 5 miles away.
Lions spend up to 20 hours a day resting to conserve energy.
Male lions defend the pride's territory while females do most of the hunting.

randomAnimals.name: koala
facts: They rarely drink water, getting most of their hydration from eucalyptus leaves.
They sleep up to 20 hours a day due to their low-energy eucalyptus leaf diet.
Koalas are not bears; they are marsupials and carry their young in a pouch.
Koalas have unique fingerprints, similar to humans and primates.
